page.title: 12HOUSING IN SOUTH GODSTONE
page.content: This area is mainly farmland with scattered farmhouses and cottages. The development of the village of South Godstone shows two main growth times; the mid 1850s with the coming of the railway, and the mid 1950s with the increase in road transport( mostly private cars). There are terraced, semi-detached and detached houses, and a few late Victorian and Edwardian Country houses on the outskirts of the village. Two small blocks of flats are found in Easter Way. The usual building material is brick with tiled roofs; the walls are sometimes rendered and colour-washed. Central heating, wall insulation and double-glazing to increase and regulate the warmth indoors, are increasingly to be found. Fireplaces and chimneys are of little importance.
